image.altText: Paul Cors with his hand on the scope of a gun wearing protective ear muffs.

props.synopsis: A former deputy mayor who killed his elderly mother almost six years ago has been found guilty of her murder after a jury rejected his mental impairment defence.

title.children: Ex-deputy mayor who killed elderly mother found guilty of murder

image.altText: A composite image of an older man and an older woman smiling.

props.synopsis: A Victorian Supreme Court jury has heard the remains of slain campers Russell Hill and Carol Clay were so damaged by fire that an expert could not determine how they died.Â

title.children: 'Evidence has been obliterated': Pathologist unable to determine cause of campers Russell Hill and Carol Clay's death

image.altText: A designed artist's graphic of a man and a kit home.

props.synopsis: These tiny homes were sold to Australians as part of a solution to the nation's housing crisis. The company involved took the money for them but never delivered.

title.children: 'Want my money back': Australians caught in tiny homes 'rip-off' demand action

image.altText: Parliament House shrouded in fog.

props.synopsis: It's the government department tasked with protecting Australia's democracy, yet within it bubble accusations of a toxic culture, the silencing of dissent and the routine cover-up of problems.

title.children: It's tasked with protecting Australia's democracy. But inside bubble accusations of a toxic culture

image.altText: Composite image between Bruce Lehrmann and Lisa Wilkinson.

props.synopsis: Lawyers in a battle over costs in the failed defamation action by former Liberal staffer Bruce Lehrmann are given a month to arrive at a dollar figure.

title.children: Lisa Wilkinson seeking $1.8m over Bruce Lehrmann's failed defamation case, Federal Court hears

image.altText: Hawthorn Hawks signage at the clubs headquarters in Melbourne

props.synopsis: The manager for Alastair Clarkson and Chris Fagan confirms the Australian Human Rights Commission has ended the claim in the wake of the parties failing to find a resolution.

title.children: Mediation talks break down in Hawthorn historical mistreatment case at Australian Human Rights Commission

image.altText: A graphic design of a document with redacted sections and words highlighted, including "very racist" and "upsetting".

props.synopsis: It was billed as a "really impactful" look at Victoria Police's response to youth gangs.Â In the aftermath, attendees complained they should have been warned they would see "someone get stabbed to death".

title.children: 'Very racist': Police hosted a youth crime seminar for government staff. An hour later the emails started

image.altText: The entry to Mount Scopus Memorial College, a rendered white fence with an Australian and Jewish flag

props.synopsis: Mount Scopus Memorial College was the target of an anti-Semitic graffiti attack that MPs have labelled an 'appalling act'.

title.children: 'It has no place in Australia': An anti-Semitic attack on a Victorian school condemned by politicians

image.altText: A mother and daughter named Jennifer and Gretl Petelczyc smiling happily in a photo.

props.synopsis: The murder of two Perth women in their own home has shocked WA and turned political attention to whether the state's proposed new gun laws are tough enough.

title.children: 'Abhorrent, gutless act': Perth murder-suicide labelled act of domestic violence

image.altText: A TV shows Grayson Murray smiling

props.synopsis: The parents of Grayson Murray, who died age 30 on Saturday, say he was loved and will be missed after his unexpected death.

title.children: 'He was loved and he will be missed': Parents of golfer Grayson Murray speak after the 30-year-old's shock death

image.altText: An older man looking into the camera

props.synopsis: Police are searching the region around Heathcote for local farmer and real estate agency owner Patrick Connally, who was last seen driving his 4WD with a full tank of petrol on Friday.

title.children: Police search underway for missing Victorian farmer and real estate agency owner

image.altText: A quarantine sign on a farm gate

props.synopsis: A farmer in south-west Victoria is in the process of killing more than 500,000 chickens this week to help stop the spread of bird flu throughÂ Australia's poultry industry.

title.children: Farmer 'devastated' at having to cull 500,000 chickens after bird flu detected

image.altText: An illustration of an electric car and a petrol car.Â

props.synopsis: Whether you drive an electric car or are considering making the switch, you've probably been drawn into a discussion about whether they are really better for the climate. To save you from your next barbecue encounter, we have put two cars to the test.

title.children: Are electric cars really greener than petrol cars? We've lined up two SUVs and put them to the test

image.altText: photo of woman standing with a serious look on her face

props.synopsis: There is a small sign in Western Victoria âÂ one of 15 locations around the country, from creeks and waterholes to bores and mountains â that is a racist slur in plain sight.

title.children: More than a dozen locations bear this racist term and relic of colonial oppression

image.altText: Brunette man looking into sun with crowd behind him in housing estate

props.synopsis: Landowners are facing massive bills and unable to build after the state government identified potential contamination on hundreds of blocks in a residential development east of Melbourne.Â

title.children: Victorians lose '$150k' in land value after hundreds of lots are deemed possibly contaminated in Wonthaggi

image.altText: Men try to lift a boulder as they dig for buried villagers following a landslide in Enga province, Papua New Guinea.Â

props.synopsis: Papua New Guinea's government has warned the death toll from Friday's landslide in Enga province could jump dramatically.

title.children: People using bare hands to recover villagers in PNG landslide, with fears of up to 2,000 people buried

image.altText: Troops in uniform walk away from the camera holding riot shields in the street

props.synopsis: A state of emergency declared in New Caledonia following riots that have left seven people and hundreds arrested is expected to end on Tuesday morning.

title.children: French government to lift New Caledonia's state of emergency in bid to ease tensions on riot-hit island

image.altText: Rishi Runak walks alongside military recruits.

props.synopsis: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has announced his party will bring back mandatory national service if they win the UK general election. What does this mean?Â

title.children: It's been called 'bonkers' and a joke', but here's how PM Rishi Sunak wants to put his country's teenagers to work

image.altText: Bonza remaining planes on tarmac

props.synopsis: The Federal Court grants an extension so the airline can try and avoid liquidation, meaning employees will remain stood down without pay and unable to accept other work for a further two months.

title.children: Bonza staff futures remain in limbo as administrators given more time to find a buyer

image.altText: A person getting off a bus in Brisbane.

props.synopsis: Queenslanders will pay 50 cents for each trip on a train, bus and ferry from August 5 for any distance and in any direction.Â

title.children: Donna spends $90 travelling to Brisbane for work every week. A new trial will see that slashed to $5

image.altText: A composite image of a man in black and white in the foreground, wielding an axe. Behind is a smashed car, red dirt and a ho

props.synopsis: Australia's domestic violence scourge is dominating headlines around the country. But in country towns like this one, harrowing stories of abuse are just another Monday.

title.children: It's a Monday morning in an outback courthouse and 73 people are waiting outside

image.altText: Jess and Gabby

props.synopsis: Baby Boomers who used telex machines in their first jobs are working alongside Generation Z colleagues who have always had a smartphone. With more of us living â and working â for longer, how are we making it work?

title.children: Baby boomers are sharing offices with Generation Z â and they're learning plenty from each other

image.altText: a crowd of people walking on a dirty road, two people carry a stretcher made out of tree branches.

props.synopsis: The International Organisation for Migration's chief of mission in Papua New Guinea said the scale of impact was greater than initially thought.Â

title.children: UN agency says more than 670 people feared dead after Papua New Guinea landslide

image.altText: Fire rages following an Israeli strike on an area designated for displaced Palestinians, in Gaza.

props.synopsis: Israeli air strikes kill at least 35 Palestinians and wound dozens in an area in the southern Gaza Strip city of Rafah designated for the displaced, Palestinian health and civil emergency service officials say.

title.children: Israeli strike on Rafah, where displaced Gazans are sheltering, kills 35 days after ICJ ruling

image.altText: A defaced electoral sign.

props.synopsis: In the first Reconciliation Week since the defeat of the Voice to Parliament, the inability of our national discourse to reflect on its significance is stunning.Â It is, again, Indigenous people who have quietly been doing the heavy lifting on what should come next.

title.children: Since the Voice to Parliament's defeat, has the Great Australian Silence been extended into perpetuity?

image.altText: Police standing at a police car.

props.synopsis: Victoria Police is investigating after two teenagers were stabbed during a fight that broke out in St Albans on Saturday night.Â

title.children: Two teenagers have been left with serious injuries after they were stabbed during a fight in Melbourne's north-west

image.altText: An aerial view of the SKA-Low being built

props.synopsis: By 2030, the world's largest radio telescope will be operational in remote Western Australia, but by then tens of thousands of satellites will be blanketing Earth's orbit with radio noise.

title.children: Could increasing satellite 'noise' pose problems for the Square Kilometre Array?

image.altText: Protesters sit down and chant at the Australian National University pro-Palestine encampment.

props.synopsis: Protesters at a pro-Palestine encampment are given a deadline of midday tomorrow to leave or risk facing further police involvement.

title.children: Students given deadline to leave pro-Palestine encampment at Australian National University

image.altText: A stock trader looks down at a tablet as he works on the floor of a busy stock exchange while surrounded by screens.

props.synopsis: The ASX gained steadily across the day, closing 0.8% higher, just shy of a record close. Look back on the day's financial news and insights from our specialist business reporters as it happened on our blog.

title.children: As it happened: ASX up 0.8pc, just shy of a record close

image.altText: A split image shows Ebrahim Raisi with light grey beard and rimless glasses, Benjamin Netanyahu wearing black shirt

props.synopsis: Two of the great adversaries of our time are facing significant internal turmoil with the death of the Iranian president and fresh allegations of war crimes against Israel's leaders. The consequences will play out on the global stage.

title.children: Two bitter rivals are dealing with internal crises. What happens next will have ramifications for the rest of the world

image.altText: A composite image ofÂ Rawdah Mohamed, Viola Davis, Elle Fanning and Bella Hadid at Cannes 2024.Â

props.synopsis: With screening after screening, there are a lot of red carpet events at the French festival. Here's a quick recap of some of the looks we saw this year.Â

title.children: Red carpet: Cannes Film Festival wraps up a marathon of fashion

image.altText: Kylie Kwong sits at a table in an empty restaurant. She wears all black, thick-rimmed glasses and hand is on her chin

props.synopsis: Kylie Kwong has been at the top of the Australian food scene for three decades. Now, she reveals her surprising next chapter as she continues to channel unimaginable grief into a force for good.

title.children: Kylie Kwong worked 'like a maniac' to process her tsunami of grief. Her son's spirit has sparked a life-changing shift
